p: We built a base of approximately 150 oral histories of Hurricane Maria and its effect on the people of Puerto Rico. In looking at these oral histories, I realized that their overarching message when we read them together as a polyphonic history of the disaster is community response to climate disaster; the stories again and again celebrate what the neighbor does, what the person down the street does, what the church does, what the people gather together to do—to feed, to shelter, to provide clean drinking water. Again and again, the oral histories talk about the limitations or abject failures of relief efforts coming from federal and local government levels.
